member.summary: Immediately cancel a fine-tune job.

member.name: M:OpenAI.Interfaces.IFineTuneService.ListFineTuneEvents(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get fine-grained status updates for a fine-tune job.
member.param: The ID of the fine-tune job to get events for.

Whether to stream events for the fine-tune job. If set to true, events will be sent as data-only server-sent events as they become available. The stream will terminate with a data: [DONE] message when the job is finished (succeeded, cancelled, or failed). If set to false, only events generated so far will be returned.
Propagates notification that operations should be canceled.

member.name: T:OpenAI.Interfaces.IModerationService
member.summary: Given a input text, outputs if the model classifies it as violating OpenAI's content policy. Related guide: Moderations

member.name: M:OpenAI.Interfaces.IModerationService.CreateModeration(OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CreateModerationRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Classifies if text violates OpenAI's Content Policy
member.param: Propagates notification that operations should be canceled.

member.name: M:OpenAI.Interfaces.IModerationServiceExtension.CreateModeration(OpenAI.Interfaces.IModerationService,System.String,System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Classifies if text violates OpenAI's Content Policy
member.param: The input text to classify

Two content moderations models are available: text-moderation-stable and text-moderation-latest. The default is text-moderation-latest which will be automatically upgraded over time. This ensures you are always using our most accurate model. If you use text-moderation-stable, we will provide advanced notice before updating the model. Accuracy of text-moderation-stable may be slightly lower than for text-moderation-latest.
Propagates notification that operations should be canceled.

member.name: T:OpenAI.Managers.OpenAIService.ReassemblyContext
member.summary: This helper class attempts to reassemble a function call response that was split up across several streamed chunks. Note that this only works for the first message in each response, and ignores the others; if OpenAI ever changes their response format this will need to be adjusted.

member.name: M:OpenAI.Managers.OpenAIService.ReassemblyContext.Process(OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.ChatCompletionCreateResponse)
member.summary: Detects if a response block is a part of a multi-chunk streamed function call response. As long as that's true, it keeps accumulating block contents, and once function call streaming is done, it produces the assembled results in the final block.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4
member.summary: More capable than any GPT-3.5 model, able to do more complex tasks, and optimized for chat. Will be updated with our latest model iteration. 8,192 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_32k
member.summary: Same capabilities as the base gpt-4 mode but with 4x the context length. Will be updated with our latest model iteration. 32,768 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_0314
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-4 from March 14th 2023. Unlike gpt-4, this model will not receive updates, and will only be supported for a three month period ending on June 14th 2023. 8,192 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_32k_0314
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-4-32 from March 14th 2023. Unlike gpt-4-32k, this model will not receive updates, and will only be supported for a three month period ending on June 14th 2023. 32,768 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_0613
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-4 from June 13th 2023 with function calling data. Unlike gpt-4, this model will not receive updates, and will be deprecated 3 months after a new version is released. 8,192 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_32k_0613
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-4-32 from June 13th 2023. Unlike gpt-4-32k, this model will not receive updates, and will be deprecated 3 months after a new version is released. 32,768 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_1106_preview
member.summary: The latest GPT-4 model with improved instruction following, JSON mode, reproducible outputs, parallel function calling, and more. Returns a maximum of 4,096 output tokens. This preview model is not yet suited for production traffic. 128,000 tokens Up to Apr 2023

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_4_vision_preview
member.summary: Ability to understand images, in addition to all other GPT-4 Turbo capabilties. Returns a maximum of 4,096 output tokens. This is a preview model version and not suited yet for production traffic. 128,000 tokens Up to Apr 2023

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.ChatGpt3_5Turbo
member.summary: Most capable GPT-3.5 model and optimized for chat at 1/10th the cost of text-davinci-003. Will be updated with our latest model iteration. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo
member.summary: Most capable GPT-3.5 model and optimized for chat at 1/10th the cost of text-davinci-003. Will be updated with our latest model iteration. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_16k
member.summary: Same capabilities as the standard gpt-3.5-turbo model but with 4 times the context. 16,384 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.ChatGpt3_5Turbo0301
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-3.5-turbo from March 1st 2023. Unlike gpt-3.5-turbo, this model will not receive updates, and will only be supported for a three month period ending on June 1st 2023. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_0301
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-3.5-turbo from March 1st 2023. Unlike gpt-3.5-turbo, this model will not receive updates, and will only be supported for a three month period ending on June 1st 2023. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_0613
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-3.5-turbo from June 13th 2023 with function calling data. Unlike gpt-3.5-turbo, this model will not receive updates, and will be deprecated 3 months after a new version is released. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_1106
member.summary: The latest GPT-3.5 Turbo model with improved instruction following, JSON mode, reproducible outputs, parallel function calling, and more. 16,384 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_16k_0613
member.summary: Snapshot of gpt-3.5-turbo from June 13th 2023 with function calling data. Unlike gpt-3.5-turbo, this model will not receive updates, and will be deprecated 3 months after a new version is released. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Gpt_3_5_Turbo_Instruct
member.summary: Similar capabilities as text-davinci-003 but compatible with legacy Completions endpoint and not Chat Completions. 4,096 tokens Up to Sep 2021

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Dall_e_2
member.summary: The previous DALL·E model released in Nov 2022. The 2nd iteration of DALL·E with more realistic, accurate, and 4x greater resolution images than the original model.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Dall_e_3
member.summary: The latest DALL·E model released in Nov 2023.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Tts_1
member.summary: TTS is an AI model that converts text to natural sounding spoken text. tts-1 is optimized for real time text to speech use cases. Released in Nov 2023.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Tts_1_hd
member.summary: TTS is an AI model that converts text to natural sounding spoken text. tts-1-hd is optimized for quality Released in Nov 2023.

member.name: M:OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.ModelNameBuilder(OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.BaseModel,System.Nullable{OpenAI.ObjectModels.Models.Subject},System.String)
member.summary: This method does not guarantee returned model exists.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateSpeechRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use. One of the available TTS models: tts-1 or tts-1-hd

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateSpeechRequest.Input
member.summary: The text to generate audio for. The maximum length is 4096 characters.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateSpeechRequest.Voice
member.summary: The voice to use when generating the audio. Supported voices are alloy, echo, fable, onyx, nova, and shimmer

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateSpeechRequest.ResponseFormat
member.summary: The format to audio in. Supported formats are mp3, opus, aac, and flac Defaults to mp3

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateSpeechRequest.Speed
member.summary: The speed of the generated audio. Select a value from 0.25 to 4.0. Defaults to 1.0

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.Prompt
member.summary: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.ResponseFormat
member.summary: The format of the transcript output, in one of these options: json, text, srt, verbose_json, or vtt.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.Language
member.summary: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 format will improve accuracy and latency.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.File
member.summary: The audio file to transcribe, in one of these formats: mp3, mp4, mpeg, mpga, m4a, wav, or webm.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.FileStream
member.summary: The stream of the audio file to transcribe, in one of these formats: mp3, mp4, mpeg, mpga, m4a, wav, or webm.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.FileName
member.summary: FileName

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use. Only whisper-1 is currently available.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.AudioCreateTranscriptionRequest.Temperature
member.summary: The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use log probability to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Messages
member.summary: The messages to generate chat completions for, in the chat format. The main input is the messages parameter. Messages must be an array of message objects, where each object has a role (either “system”, “user”, or “assistant”) and content (the content of the message). Conversations can be as short as 1 message or fill many pages.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Functions
member.summary: A list of functions the model may generate JSON inputs for.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.TopP
member.summary: An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.N
member.summary: How many chat completion choices to generate for each input message.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Stream
member.summary: If set, partial message deltas will be sent, like in ChatGPT. Tokens will be sent as data-only server-sent events as they become available, with the stream terminated by a data: [DONE] message.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Stop
member.summary: Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.StopAsList
member.summary: Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary: The maximum number of tokens allowed for the generated answer. By default, the number of tokens the model can return will be (4096 - prompt tokens).

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.LogitBias
member.summary: Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a json object that maps tokens(specified by their token ID in the GPT tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. You can use this tokenizer tool (which works for both GPT-2 and GPT-3) to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token. As an example, you can pass { "50256": -100} to prevent the endoftext token from being generated.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.FunctionCall
member.summary: String or object. Controls how the model responds to function calls. "none" means the model does not call a function, and responds to the end-user. "auto" means the model can pick between an end-user or calling a function. "none" is the default when no functions are present. "auto" is the default if functions are present. Specifying a particular function via {"name": "my_function"} forces the model to call that function. (Note: in C# specify that as: FunctionCall = new Dictionary<string, string> { { "name", "my_function" } } ).

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.ResponseFormat
P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.ChatResponseFormat
member.summary: The format that the model must output. Used to enable JSON mode. Must be one of "text" or "json_object".
member.exception: Thrown when an unsupported value is provided.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Seed
member.summary: This feature is in Beta. If specified, our system will make a best effort to sample deterministically, such that repeated requests with the same seed and parameters should return the same result. Determinism is not guaranteed, and you should refer to the system_fingerprint response parameter to monitor changes in the backend.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use. For models supported see start with Gpt_

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.Temperature
member.summary: What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatCompletionCreateRequest.User
member.summary: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. Learn more.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage
member.summary: The contents of the message. Messages must be an array of message objects, where each object has a role (either “system”, “user”, or “assistant”) and content (the content of the message) and an optional name

member.name: M:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionCall)
member.param: The role of the author of this message. One of system, user, or assistant.
The contents of the message.
The name of the author of this message. May contain a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and underscores, with a maximum length of 64 characters.
The name and arguments of a function that should be called, as generated by the model.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage.Role
member.summary: The role of the author of this message. One of system, user, or assistant.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage.Content
member.summary: The contents of the message.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage.Name
member.summary: The name of the author of this message. May contain a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and underscores, with a maximum length of 64 characters.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ChatMessage.FunctionCall
member.summary: The name and arguments of a function that should be called, as generated by the model.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest
member.summary: Create Completion Request Model

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Prompt
member.summary: The prompt(s) to generate completions for, encoded as a string, a list of strings, or a list of token lists. Note that endoftext is the document separator that the model sees during training, so if a prompt is not specified the model will generate as if from the beginning of a new document.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.PromptAsList
member.summary: The prompt(s) to generate completions for, encoded as a string, a list of strings, or a list of token lists. Note that endoftext is the document separator that the model sees during training, so if a prompt is not specified the model will generate as if from the beginning of a new document.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Suffix
member.summary: The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. The token count of your prompt plus max_tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens (except davinci-codex, which supports 4096).

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.TopP
member.summary: An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.N
member.summary: Defaults to 1 How many completions to generate for each prompt. Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Stream
member.summary:
Whether to stream back partial progress. If set, tokens will be sent as data-only
server-sent events
as they become available, with the stream terminated by a data: [DONE] message.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Echo
member.summary: Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Stop
member.summary: Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.StopAsList
member.summary: Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.BestOf
member.summary: Generates best_of completions server-side and returns the "best" (the one with the lowest log probability per token). Results cannot be streamed. When used with n, best_of controls the number of candidate completions and n specifies how many to return – best_of must be greater than n. Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.LogitBias
member.summary: Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion. Accepts a json object that maps tokens(specified by their token ID in the GPT tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. You can use this tokenizer tool (which works for both GPT-2 and GPT-3) to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token. As an example, you can pass { "50256": -100} to prevent the endoftext token from being generated.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.LogProbs
member.summary: Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, as well the chosen tokens. For example, if logprobs is 5, the API will return a list of the 5 most likely tokens. The API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response. The maximum value for logprobs is 5. If you need more than this, please contact support@openai.com and describe your use case.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.Temperature
member.summary: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CompletionCreateRequest.User
member.summary: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which will help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CreateModerationRequest.InputAsList
member.summary: The input text to classify

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CreateModerationRequest.Input
member.summary: The input text to classify

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.CreateModerationRequest.Model
member.summary: Two content moderations models are available: text-moderation-stable and text-moderation-latest. The default is text-moderation-latest which will be automatically upgraded over time. This ensures you are always using our most accurate model. If you use text-moderation-stable, we will provide advanced notice before updating the model. Accuracy of text-moderation-stable may be slightly lower than for text-moderation-latest.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest
member.summary: Create Edit Request Model

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest.Input
member.summary: The input text to use as a starting point for the edit.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest.Instruction
member.summary: The instruction that tells the model how to edit the prompt.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest.N
member.summary: Defaults to 1 How many completions to generate for each prompt. Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest.TopP
member.summary: An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EditCreateRequest.Temperature
member.summary: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EmbeddingCreateRequest.InputAsList
member.summary: Input text to get embeddings for, encoded as a string or array of tokens. To get embeddings for multiple inputs in a single request, pass an array of strings or array of token arrays. Each input must not exceed 2048 tokens in length. Unless your are embedding code, we suggest replacing newlines (`\n`) in your input with a single space, as we have observed inferior results when newlines are present.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EmbeddingCreateRequest.Input
member.summary: Input text to get embeddings for, encoded as a string or array of tokens. To get embeddings for multiple inputs in a single request, pass an array of strings or array of token arrays. Each input must not exceed 2048 tokens in length. Unless your are embedding code, we suggest replacing newlines (`\n`) in your input with a single space, as we have observed inferior results when newlines are present.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.EmbeddingCreateRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use. You can use the [List models](/docs/api-reference/models/list) API to see all of your available models, or see our [Model overview](/docs/models/overview) for descriptions of them.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.TrainingFile
member.summary: The ID of an uploaded file that contains training data. See upload file for how to upload a file. Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file, where each training example is a JSON object with the keys "prompt" and "completion". Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune. See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.ValidationFile
member.summary:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains validation data. If you provide this file, the data is used to generate validation metrics periodically during fine-tuning. These metrics can be viewed in the
fine-tuning results file
. Your train and validation data should be mutually exclusive. Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file, where each validation example is a JSON object with the keys "prompt" and "completion". Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune. See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.NEpochs
member.summary: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset. Set -1 for "auto value

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.BatchSize
member.summary: The batch size to use for training. The batch size is the number of training examples used to train a single forward and backward pass. By default, the batch size will be dynamically configured to be ~0.2% of the number of examples in the training set, capped at 256 - in general, we've found that larger batch sizes tend to work better for larger datasets.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.LearningRateMultiplier
member.summary: The learning rate multiplier to use for training. The fine-tuning learning rate is the original learning rate used for pretraining multiplied by this value. By default, the learning rate multiplier is the 0.05, 0.1, or 0.2 depending on final batch_size(larger learning rates tend to perform better with larger batch sizes). We recommend experimenting with values in the range 0.02 to 0.2 to see what produces the best results.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.PromptLossWeight
member.summary: The weight to use for loss on the prompt tokens. This controls how much the model tries to learn to generate the prompt (as compared to the completion which always has a weight of 1.0), and can add a stabilizing effect to training when completions are short. If prompts are extremely long (relative to completions), it may make sense to reduce this weight so as to avoid over-prioritizing learning the prompt.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.ComputeClassificationMetrics
member.summary: If set, we calculate classification-specific metrics such as accuracy and F-1 score using the validation set at the end of every epoch.These metrics can be viewed in the results file. In order to compute classification metrics, you must provide a validation_file.Additionally, you must specify classification_n_classes for multiclass classification or classification_positive_class for binary classification.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationNClasses
member.summary: The number of classes in a classification task. This parameter is required for multiclass classification.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationPositiveClass
member.summary: The positive class in binary classification. This parameter is needed to generate precision, recall, and F1 metrics when doing binary classification.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationBetas
member.summary: If this is provided, we calculate F-beta scores at the specified beta values. The F-beta score is a generalization of F-1 score. This is only used for binary classification. With a beta of 1 (i.e.the F-1 score), precision and recall are given the same weight.A larger beta score puts more weight on recall and less on precision. A smaller beta score puts more weight on precision and less on recall.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.Suffix
member.summary: A string of up to 40 characters that will be added to your fine-tuned model name. For example, a suffix of "custom-model-name" would produce a model name like ada:ft-your-org:custom-model-name-2022-02-15-04-21-04.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuneCreateRequest.Model
member.summary: The name of the base model to fine-tune. You can select one of "ada", "babbage", or "curie". To learn more about these models, see the Models documentation.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobCreateRequest.TrainingFile
member.summary: The ID of an uploaded file that contains training data. See upload file for how to upload a file. Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file. Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune. See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobCreateRequest.ValidationFile
member.summary: The ID of an uploaded file that contains validation data. If you provide this file, the data is used to generate validation metrics periodically during fine-tuning. These metrics can be viewed in the fine-tuning results file. The same data should not be present in both train and validation files. Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file. You must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune. See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobCreateRequest.Hyperparameters
member.summary: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobCreateRequest.Suffix
member.summary: A string of up to 18 characters that will be added to your fine-tuned model name. For example, a suffix of "custom-model-name" would produce a model name like ft:gpt-3.5-turbo:openai:custom-model-name:7p4lURel.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobCreateRequest.Model
member.summary: The name of the model to fine-tune. You can select one of the supported models .

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.HyperparametersRequestModel.NEpochs
member.summary: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset. "Auto" decides the optimal number of epochs based on the size of the dataset. If setting the number manually, we support any number between 1 and 50 epochs. "Auto" == -1

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobListEventsRequest.FineTuningJobId
member.summary: The ID of the fine-tuning job to get events for.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobListRequest.After
member.summary: Identifier for the last job from the previous pagination request.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FineTuningJobListRequest.Limit
member.summary: Number of fine-tuning jobs to retrieve. Defaults to 20.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionCall
member.summary: Describes a function call returned from GPT. A function call contains a function name, and a dictionary mapping function argument names to their values.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionCall.Name
member.summary: Function name

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionCall.Arguments
member.summary: Function arguments, returned as a JSON-encoded dictionary mapping argument names to argument values.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionDefinition
member.summary: Definition of a valid function call.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionDefinition.Name
member.summary: Required. The name of the function to be called. Must be a-z, A-Z, 0-9, or contain underscores and dashes, with a maximum length of 64.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionDefinition.Description
member.summary: Optional. The description of what the function does.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.FunctionDefinition.Parameters
member.summary: Optional. The parameters the functions accepts, described as a JSON Schema object. See the guide (https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/gpt/function-calling) for examples, and the JSON Schema reference (https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/) for documentation about the format.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageCreateRequest
member.summary: Image Create Request Model

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageCreateRequest.Prompt
member.summary: A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 1000 characters for dall-e-2 and 4000 characters for dall-e-3

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageCreateRequest.Quality
member.summary:
The quality of the image that will be generated. Must be hd. Hd creates images with finer details and greater consistency across the image. This param is only supported for dall-e-3 model.
Check for possible values

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageCreateRequest.Style
member.summary:
The style of the generated images. Must be one of vivid or natural. Vivid causes the model to lean towards generating hyper-real and dramatic images. Natural causes the model to produce more natural, less hyper-real looking images. This param is only supported for dall-e-3.
Check for possible values

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageEditCreateRequest.Image
member.summary: The image to edit. Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and square.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageEditCreateRequest.ImageName
member.summary: Image file name

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageEditCreateRequest.Mask
member.summary: An additional image whose fully transparent areas (e.g. where alpha is zero) indicate where image should be edited. Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and have the same dimensions as image.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageEditCreateRequest.MaskName
member.summary: Mask file name

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageEditCreateRequest.Prompt
member.summary: A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 1000 characters.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageVariationCreateRequest.Image
member.summary: The image to edit. Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and square.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ImageVariationCreateRequest.ImageName
member.summary: Image file name

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ResponseFormat
member.summary: An object specifying the format that the model must output. Used to enable JSON mode.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.RequestModels.ResponseFormat.Type
member.summary: Setting to json_object enables JSON mode. This guarantees that the message the model generates is valid JSON. Note that the message content may be partial if finish_reason="length", which indicates the generation exceeded max_tokens or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.AudioCreateSpeechResponse`1
member.summary: File content response

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FileResponseModels.FileContentResponse`1
member.summary: File content response

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FileResponseModels.FileContentResponse`1.Content
member.summary: Content of your file

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FileResponseModels.FileContentResponse`1.Successful
member.summary: return false if there is an error

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FileResponseModels.FileContentResponse`1.Error
member.summary: Error

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.FinishedAt
member.summary: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the fine-tuning job was finished. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.FineTunedModel
member.summary: The name of the fine-tuned model that is being created. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.OrganizationId
member.summary: The organization that owns the fine-tuning job.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.Status
member.summary: The current status of the fine-tuning job, which can be either created, pending, running, succeeded, failed, or cancelled.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.HyperparametersData
member.summary: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job. See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.TrainingFile
member.summary: The file ID used for training. You can retrieve the training data with the Files API.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.ValidationFile
member.summary: The file ID used for validation. You can retrieve the validation results with the Files API.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.ResultFiles
member.summary: The compiled results file ID(s) for the fine-tuning job. You can retrieve the results with the Files API.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.TrainedTokens
member.summary: The total number of billable tokens processed by this fine-tuning job. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.CreatedAt
member.summary: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the fine-tuning job was created.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.Id
member.summary: The object identifier, which can be referenced in the API endpoints.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.Model
member.summary: The base model that is being fine-tuned.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.ResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponseModels.FineTuningJobResponse.Hyperparameters.NEpochs
member.summary: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset. "Auto" decides the optimal number of epochs based on the size of the dataset. If setting the number manually, we support any number between 1 and 50 epochs. "Auto" == -1

member.name: T:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition
member.summary: Function parameter is a JSON Schema object. https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference/object.html

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Type
member.summary: Required. Function parameter object type. Default value is "object".

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Properties
member.summary: Optional. List of "function arguments", as a dictionary that maps from argument name to an object that describes the type, maybe possible enum values, and so on.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Required
member.summary: Optional. List of "function arguments" which are required.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.AdditionalProperties
member.summary: Optional. Whether additional properties are allowed. Default value is true.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Description
member.summary: Optional. Argument description.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Enum
member.summary: Optional. List of allowed values for this argument.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.MinProperties
member.summary: The number of properties on an object can be restricted using the minProperties and maxProperties keywords. Each of these must be a non-negative integer.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.MaxProperties
member.summary: The number of properties on an object can be restricted using the minProperties and maxProperties keywords. Each of these must be a non-negative integer.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.Items
member.summary: If type is "array", this specifies the element type for all items in the array. If type is not "array", this should be null. For more details, see https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference/array.html

member.name: M:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.ConvertTypeToString(OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.PropertyDefinition.FunctionObjectTypes)

member.param: The type to convert

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.SharedImageRequestBaseModel.N
member.summary: The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10. For dall-e-3 model, only n=1 is supported.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.SharedImageRequestBaseModel.Size
member.summary: The size of the generated images. Must be one of 256x256, 512x512, or 1024x1024 for dall-e-2. Must be one of 1024x1024, 1792x1024, or 1024x1792 for dall-e-3 models.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.SharedImageRequestBaseModel.ResponseFormat
member.summary: The format in which the generated images are returned. Must be one of url or b64_json

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.SharedImageRequestBaseModel.User
member.summary: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which will help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. Learn more.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.SharedModels.SharedImageRequestBaseModel.Model
member.summary: The model to use for image generation. Must be one of dall-e-2 or dall-e-3 For ImageEditCreateRequest and for ImageVariationCreateRequest only dall-e-2 modell is supported at this time.

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.StaticValues.ImageStatics.Size.Size1792x1024
member.summary: Only dall-e-3 model

member.name: P:OpenAI.ObjectModels.StaticValues.ImageStatics.Size.Size1024x1792
member.summary: Only dall-e-3 model

member.name: P:OpenAI.OpenAiOptions.Organization
member.summary: For users who belong to multiple organizations, you can pass a header to specify which organization is used for an API request. Usage from these API requests will count against the specified organization's subscription quota. Organization IDs can be found on your Organization settings page.

member.name: P:OpenAI.OpenAiOptions.ApiKey
member.summary: The OpenAI API uses API keys for authentication. Visit your API Keys page to retrieve the API key you'll use in your requests. Remember that your API key is a secret! Do not share it with others or expose it in any client-side code(browsers, apps). Production requests must be routed through your own backend server where your API key can be securely loaded from an environment variable or key management service.
